titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Southern Cone Collection
titlestmt.author: compiled by Philip S. MacLeod and Christine Weideman

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:04

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: A collection of correspondence; government documents; published illustrated materials; and writings from the Southern Cone region of Latin America (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay) on civil, military, economic and social topics.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: The entire collection, with the exception of Accession 2013-M-023, is available on microfilm and may be purchased from Gale Group, Farmington Hills, Michigan.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Materials have been assembled from various collections and acquired from several individuals. They include materials transferred from the Latin American Collection Curator, Yale University Library, 2012-2015.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The entire collection, with the exception of Accession 2013-M-023, is available on microfilm. Patrons must use FILM HM 251 instead of the originals.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown, though much of the material in this collection is likely in the public domain. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Southern Cone Collection. Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged alphabetically by country, and by date within country.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence; government documents; published illustrated materials; and writings from the Southern Cone region of Latin America (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay). The collection is arranged by country, and by date within country. The description of each item includes, when possible, its author, title, place of origin, and a summary of its contents. When an item is a copy of an original, it is arranged by the date of the original. The date field, however, contains the date of the copy itself, not the original. The date of the original is included in the summary description of the item.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is comprised of originals and copies of materials from Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay. The majority pertain to Argentinian history from the late eighteenth century to the middle of the present century. Of particular significance is a nineteenth century bound volume bearing the imprint "De Don Jose San Martin." It contains numerous handwritten passages drawn from philosophical texts, religious and political treatises, as well as literary works, which reflect the education and thinking of this leader of South American independence. A summary of documents dealing with the abortive Alzaga rebellion, written by the acting Viceroy, discusses the political situation in Argentina just prior to independence. Materials about Buenos Aires's La Boca neighborhood are useful for the study of Italian immigration to Argentina, and the history of the Argentine-Italian community. Of note regarding Paraguay are handwritten copies of several little-known texts that deal with the country's history in the early nineteenth century.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Patrons must use microfilm on FILM HM 251 instead of the originals.

did.unittitle: Title: Novedades de Buenos Aires. Place: Buenos Aires. Description: Notice of the arrival of a ship, believed to have been lost on an expedition along the Patagonian coast, bringing news of further discoveries and of a potential English presence in the region.

Author: Linier, Santiago de. Title: Summary by the viceroy of the Rio de la Plata. Place: Buenos Aires. Description: Summary of the contents of documents sent to the Spanish Crown which deal with the abortive rebellion led by Martin de Alzaga and prior events in Buenos Aires. Also discussed is the situation in Montevideo involving Francisco Elio, British and Portuguese involvement in the area, and events in Spain.

Title: "Testimonio del expediente obrado sobre el apresamiento de la fragata Triton y su cargamento, correspondiente a Real Compania de Filipinas...." Place: Buenos Aires. Description: Documents dealing with the seizure of the Triton by the navy of the United Provinces of La Plata. The ship belonged to the Royal Spanish Company of the Philippines and was sailing from Calcutta to Cadiz. Included are a cargo manifest, testimonies by sailors and translations of papers in English taken from the Triton.

Title: "Congreso de las Provincias Unidas del Rio de la Plata" Place: Buenos Aires? Description: Speech calling for an end to civil wars and for the people to accept the new constitution. The discourse condemns Simon Bolivar for creating a despotic state in Bolivia and his occupation of the province of Tarija.

Title: Letter by Juan Manuel de Rosas to Manuel Jose Garcia. Place: Rio Colorado. Description: Rosas acknowledges receipt of Garcia's letter of November 7 and states that he will shortly answer the letters of Mr. Guido. Includes typescript transcription and English translation.

Title: Letter by Jose Justo de Urquiza to Marcelo Cerrutti. Place: San Jose. Description: Letter by Jose Justo de Urquiza to the "Encargado de Negocios" of the king of Sardinia thanking him for his offer of assistance with European correspondence. A newspaper clipping about Urquiza is attached to the letter.

Author: Sarmiento, Domingo Faustino Title: Tumba de Piñero. Place: Buenos Aires? Description: Handwritten copy or draft of a speech delivered by Domingo Faustino Sarmiento in honor of Senator Martin Piñero. Written on the official stationery of the Argentinian president.

Author: Pelliza, Mariano A. Title: The War for Argentine Independence. Place: Buenos Aires? Description: Published broadside concerning attempts by Argentinian armies to liberate northwestern Argentina and Bolivia from Spanish rule between 1809 and 1813.

Title: Compiled writings. Place: Buenos Aires? Description: A bound handwritten volume containing transcribed passages from philosophical texts, religious and political treatises, as well as prose passages and poetry. Texts are in Spanish, English and French. All transcriptions appear to be written in the same hand. A bookplate on the inside cover bears the imprint "De Don Jose San Martin."

Author: Moneta, Jose Manuel. Place: Buenos Aires. Title: "La Argentina fué el primer país que estableció el correo Antártico." Description: Newspaper article from La Prensawhich asserts Argentine sovereignty in Antarctica. It details the establishment of mail services in the Antarctic regions in 1904.

Title: "Los Cuentos de la Boca." Description: A collection of materials related to a documentary about the history of La Boca, an old Italian neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Included is a copy of the documentary; background information about the film; a brief history of La Boca; copies of photographs used in the film; photographs of the filming of the production; and copies of clippings from Italian newspapers about the film.

Author: Da Costa, Pacidonio, et. al. Title: "Primer ensayo sobre la historia del Paraguay por..." Description: Handwritten copy of several different texts which detail Paraguayan history from colonization to 1824; Paraguay's political situation in 1811-1812; and the re-establishment, reform and natural order of the "Jesuitic System" in Paraguay through 1823. Also included are an exchange of diplomatic correspondence between Brazil and Paraguay; part of the political catechism for Paraguayan youth; and correspondence between Jose Artigas, leader of Uruguay, and Juan Martin Pueyrredon, the leader of Argentina.

Title: Documents concerning shipping. Description: Two sets of documents dealing with shipping and naval affairs between Spain and Montevideo. The ships Anunciación and Los Dos Hermanos de Montevideo Victorio y Francisco are prominently discussed.

Title: "Cartas dedicadas a el recto honorable Lord N ? sobre las ultimas expediciones a la costa española....," Place: London? Description: Handwritten Spanish language copy, made by a Latin American resident of Britain, of five letters addressed to an unidentified English lord. These letters, by an unidentified author, discuss the characteristics of the area's people; the threats posed by Napoleon Bonaparte; and United States involvement in the region and why it was in Britain's interest to get involved in the emancipation of the Americas. The writer proposes a plan for England to seek an independent Mexico.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consiststs of published illustrated scenes of Buenos Aires, Argentina.

did.unittitle: Description: Two illustrations depicting Argentinian soldiers; one illustration depicting two women and a man wearing traditional Paraguayan dress; and one illustration of the Buenos Aires harbor and cityscape. Illustrators: P. Blanchau, James Langer, unknown. Publication: L'Illustration, Journal Universel , pages 296-297.

Description: One illustration depicting the Rio Della Plata, and one illustration depicting the Piazza Della Victoria in Buenos Aires. Illustrators: unknown. Publication: L'Illustrazione Italiana , page 77.
Title: "View of the City of Buenos Ayres, Argentine Republic." Illustrator: A.C.S. Publication: unknown.
Title: "Plaza Del Mercato A Buenos Ayres." Illustrator unknown. Publication: Nuovo Giornale Illustrato Universale , page 108.
Title: "Turning the First Turf of the Buenos Ayres Great Southern Railway." Illustrator unknown. Publication: The Illustrated London News , page 477.
Title: "Ruins of the Retiro Barracks, At Buenos Ayres, After the Late Explosion." Illustrator unknown. Publication: The Illustrated London News , page 80.
Title: "Views of Buenos Aires, with the Exhibition Building." Illustrator unknown. Publication: The Illustrated London News , page 261.
Title: "The New City of La Plata, Buenos Ayres, The Capital of the Argentine Republic." Publication: The Illustrated London Times , page 73.

Description: Several illustrations of street scenes and buildings in Buenos Aires, as well as portraits of several Argentinian politicians, including the country's president, vice president, and other leaders. Publication: Le Monde Illustré , pages 84-85.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession consists of late twentieth-century imprints on various trade unions in Argentina. The bulk of the materials comes from the period between 1980 and 1995. It includes materials on Asociación de Trabajadores del Estado (ATE), Federación Argentina de Trabajadores de Luz y Fuerza (FATLYF), Federación Obreros y Empleados Telefónicos de la República Argentina (FOETRA), Sindicato de Mecánicos y Afines del Transporte Automotor de la República Argentina (SMATA), Union of State Oil Workers (SUPE), and teachers' unions. Materials consist of directories, contracts, labor agreements, salary agreements, retirement issues, press releases, and other official union documents.

did.unittitle: Federación Argentina de Trabajadores de Luz y Fuerza
Federación de Obreros y Empleados Telefónicos
Sindicato del Personal de Industrias Químicas y Petroquímicas
Sindicato de Mecánicos y Afines del Transporte Automotor
Federación Sindicatos Unidos Petroleros del Estado.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in this accession include Argentinian election and political ephemera including stickers, broadsides, election lists, publications, posters, candle holders, plastic bags, buttons, newspapers and flyers. Many of the items were distributed for the May 14, 1989 election.
